document.docAuthor: Seeman, Owen D. & Palmer, Christopher M.
document.docTitle: Willungella rufusanus Seeman & Palmer, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Parasitism of Apteropanorpa tasmanica Carpenter (Mecoptera: Apteropanorpidae) by larval Leptus agrotis Southcott (Acari: Erythraeidae) and Willungella rufusanus sp. nov. (Acari: Microtrombidiidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Parasitism of Apteropanorpa tasmanica Carpenter (Mecoptera: Apteropanorpidae) by larval Leptus agrotis Southcott (Acari: Erythraeidae) and Willungella rufusanus sp. nov. (Acari: Microtrombidiidae)

Willungella rufusanus Seeman & Palmer
sp. nov. (

; Table 3 )

subSubSection.paragraph:
Holotype
. Larva,
AUSTRALIA (Tasmania)
, Mt Rufus,
23 April 2002
, C.M. Palmer, ex
Apteropanorpa tasmanica
. Holotype deposited in TMAG .

Paratypes
.
AUSTRALIA (Tasmania)
:
15 larvae
, same data as holotype . Two paratypes deposited in TMAG . Thirteen paratypes deposited in QM.

Other material examined .
6 larvae
, Mt King William I,
24 April 2002
, C.M. Palmer, ex
Apteropanorpa tasmanica
. Deposited in QM.

With characters of the genus, but femur Iâ€“III has 6, 6 , 4 setae, respectively (compared with 6, 5 , 4 in other species), and genu Iâ€“III has 3, 2 , 2 solenidia, respectively (compared with 2, 1 , 1 solenidia).

Larva. Slightly to partially fed specimens flattened on slides. Measurements in Table 3 . Idiosoma 430â€“544 long, 265â€“349 wide. Stolascutum punctate, concave at level of eyes, bearing three pairs of setae (AM, AL, PL) and a pair of sensilla (S). Setae AM and AL smooth, PL barbed; seta AL closer to PL than to AM. Eyes, anterior largest than posterior, on common sclerite.

Gnathosoma .
Capitulum 97â€“104 long, subcapitular setae barbed, 15 long, protorostral setae smooth, 9 long. Stephanostome with external cuticular sheath weakly annulate, internal sheath horse-shoe shaped, open dorsally, smooth. Palp trochanter reduced, palp femur and genu each with small dorsal seta. Palp tibia with 2 setae, 1 of these at base of odontus, odontus 9â€“11 long and trifurcate. Palp tarsus with 6 setae, solenidium, and eupathidium. Cheliceral blade sickle-shaped and with two minute subapical teeth.

96â€“104 Âµm long. Posterior dorsal scutum smooth, 72â€“81 long, 190â€“195 wide. Anus 32â€“35 long.

Coxal setae : 1 a smooth or with small fork, 43â€“46 long; 1 b forked, 39â€“49 long; 2 b forked, 45â€“47 long; 3 a barbed, 35â€“38 long, on small platelets; 3 b barbed, 39â€“44 long. Coxal plates punctate. Claparadeâ€™s organ 18â€“24 wide.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Legs . Segmentation 6 - 6 - 6 . Setal counts (trochanter to tarsus): Leg
I 1
, 6, 4, 6 , 18 ; Leg
II 1
, 6, 2, 5 , 14 ; Leg
III 1
, 4, 2, 5 , 12 . Modified leg setae: GeI, microseta Ðº and 3 solenidia Ïƒ; TiI, microseta Ðº and 2 solenidia Ï†; TaI , solenidia Ï‰, famulus Îµ, and eupathidia Î¾ 1 (Î¾ 2 absent); GeII, microseta Ðº and 2 solenidia Ïƒ; TiII, microseta Ðº + 2 solenidia Ï†; TaII, solenidia Ï‰ and famulus Îµ; GeIII, 2 solenidia Ïƒ. Leg Iâ€“II pretarsus comprising single trifurcate claw, empodium and apical eupathidium. Leg III truncate distally, with long anterior claw, apical stout claw, empodium, lophotrix (with 7 branches, 1 with setules) and barbed scopa.
The specific epithet refers to the type locality.

Although leg morphology is illustrated in detail,
Southcott ( 1994 )
did not use leg setal characters for diagnoses in his major revision of the Microtrombidiinae . However,
W . rufusanus
has additional solenidia on genu Iâ€“II, and an extra seta on femur I, but still belongs in
Willungella
as defined by
Southcott ( 1994 )
.

Leg chaetotaxy is an essential component of any acarine systematic work that deals with higher classification, and the Microtrombidiidae is no exception. However,
W. rufusanus
is very similar to other
Willungella
species except for leg chaetotaxy, supporting Southcottâ€™s reluctance to use leg chaetotaxy to define genera. Therefore, uncertainty over the usefulness of leg chaetotaxy, combined with the inability to correlate most larval and post-larval taxonomy, means an informative, phylogeny-based classification of the Microtrombidiidae is untenable at present.
